trans-unit.source: FIR Filter
trans-unit.target: FIR Filter

trans-unit.source: Creates a finite impulse response filter for signal processing
trans-unit.target: Creates a finite impulse response filter for signal processing

trans-unit.source: Category: <legacyLink xlink:href="529B4991-8A7F-4E12-8F36-51F9FACA4383" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Data Transformation / Filter</legacyLink>
trans-unit.target: Category: <legacyLink xlink:href="529B4991-8A7F-4E12-8F36-51F9FACA4383" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Data Transformation / Filter</legacyLink>

trans-unit.source: Module Overview
trans-unit.target: Module Overview

trans-unit.source: You can use the <ui>FIR Filter</ui> module to define a kind of filter called a <newTerm>finite impulse response</newTerm> (FIR) filter.
trans-unit.target: You can use the <ui>FIR Filter</ui> module to define a kind of filter called a <newTerm>finite impulse response</newTerm> (FIR) filter.

trans-unit.source: FIR filters have many applications in signal processing, and are most commonly used in applications that require a linear-phase response.
trans-unit.target: FIR filters have many applications in signal processing, and are most commonly used in applications that require a linear-phase response.

trans-unit.source: After you have defined a filter that meets your needs, you can apply the filter to data by connecting a dataset and the filter to the <link xlink:href="278e11ec-cb16-49d4-a13c-54b2c9f5ce88" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Apply Filter</link> module.
trans-unit.target: After you have defined a filter that meets your needs, you can apply the filter to data by connecting a dataset and the filter to the <link xlink:href="278e11ec-cb16-49d4-a13c-54b2c9f5ce88" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Apply Filter</link> module.

trans-unit.source: How to Configure a FIR Filter
trans-unit.target: How to Configure a FIR Filter

trans-unit.source: Specify the filter order, or the length of the filter window.
trans-unit.target: Specify the filter order, or the length of the filter window.

trans-unit.source: Choose a type of window to apply.
trans-unit.target: Choose a type of window to apply.

trans-unit.source: See the <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_Windows" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Window functions</legacyLink> section for more information about these options.
trans-unit.target: See the <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_Windows" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Window functions</legacyLink> section for more information about these options.

trans-unit.source: Choose the type of filter to create.
trans-unit.target: Choose the type of filter to create.

trans-unit.source: See the <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_FilterTypes" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Filter types</legacyLink> section for more information.
trans-unit.target: See the <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_FilterTypes" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Filter types</legacyLink> section for more information.

trans-unit.source: Depending on the type of filter you chose, set one or more cutoff values.
trans-unit.target: Depending on the type of filter you chose, set one or more cutoff values.

trans-unit.source: Connect the filter to <link xlink:href="278e11ec-cb16-49d4-a13c-54b2c9f5ce88" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Apply Filter</link>, and connect a dataset.
trans-unit.target: Connect the filter to <link xlink:href="278e11ec-cb16-49d4-a13c-54b2c9f5ce88" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Apply Filter</link>, and connect a dataset.

trans-unit.source: Use the Column Selector to specify which columns the filter should be applied to.
trans-unit.target: Use the Column Selector to specify which columns the filter should be applied to.

trans-unit.source: By default, the <link xlink:href="278e11ec-cb16-49d4-a13c-54b2c9f5ce88" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Apply Filter</link> module will use the filter for all selected numeric columns.
trans-unit.target: By default, the <link xlink:href="278e11ec-cb16-49d4-a13c-54b2c9f5ce88" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Apply Filter</link> module will use the filter for all selected numeric columns.

trans-unit.source: No computations are performed until you connect a dataset to the <link xlink:href="278e11ec-cb16-49d4-a13c-54b2c9f5ce88" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Apply Filter</link> module and run the experiment.
trans-unit.target: No computations are performed until you connect a dataset to the <link xlink:href="278e11ec-cb16-49d4-a13c-54b2c9f5ce88" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Apply Filter</link> module and run the experiment.

trans-unit.source: The <ui>FIR Filter</ui> module does not provide the option to create an indicator column.
trans-unit.target: The <ui>FIR Filter</ui> module does not provide the option to create an indicator column.

trans-unit.source: Options
trans-unit.target: Options

trans-unit.source: To define a filter, specify these values:
trans-unit.target: To define a filter, specify these values:

trans-unit.source: Order
trans-unit.target: Order

trans-unit.source: Specify an integer value to use as the <newTerm>order</newTerm> of the filter.
trans-unit.target: Specify an integer value to use as the <newTerm>order</newTerm> of the filter.

trans-unit.source: The filter order defines the number of active elements used to affect the filter's response.
trans-unit.target: The filter order defines the number of active elements used to affect the filter's response.

trans-unit.source: Window
trans-unit.target: Window

trans-unit.source: Choose the type of window to use when applying the filter coefficients.
trans-unit.target: Choose the type of window to use when applying the filter coefficients.

trans-unit.source: See the <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_Windows" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Windows Functions</legacyLink> section for details.
trans-unit.target: See the <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_Windows" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Windows Functions</legacyLink> section for details.

trans-unit.source: Filter type
trans-unit.target: Filter type

trans-unit.source: Specify the values to which the filter will be applied.
trans-unit.target: Specify the values to which the filter will be applied.

trans-unit.source: You can specify that the filter exclude the target values, alter the values, reject the values, or pass them through.
trans-unit.target: You can specify that the filter exclude the target values, alter the values, reject the values, or pass them through.

trans-unit.source: See the <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_FilterTypes" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Filter Types</legacyLink> section for details.
trans-unit.target: See the <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_FilterTypes" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Filter Types</legacyLink> section for details.

trans-unit.source: <legacyItalic><ui>High cutoff </ui></legacyItalic> and <legacyItalic><ui>Low cutoff </ui></legacyItalic>
trans-unit.target: <legacyItalic><ui>High cutoff </ui></legacyItalic> and <legacyItalic><ui>Low cutoff </ui></legacyItalic>

trans-unit.source: Define an upper and/or a lower threshold for values.
trans-unit.target: Define an upper and/or a lower threshold for values.

trans-unit.source: One or both of these options are required to specify which values are rejected or passed through.
trans-unit.target: One or both of these options are required to specify which values are rejected or passed through.

trans-unit.source: A bandstop or bandpass filter requires that you set both high and low cutoff values.
trans-unit.target: A bandstop or bandpass filter requires that you set both high and low cutoff values.

trans-unit.source: Other filter types, such as the lowpass filter, require that you set only the low cutoff value.
trans-unit.target: Other filter types, such as the lowpass filter, require that you set only the low cutoff value.

trans-unit.source: Scale
trans-unit.target: Scale

trans-unit.source: Specify whether or not scaling should be applied to coefficients.
trans-unit.target: Specify whether or not scaling should be applied to coefficients.

trans-unit.source: Filter Types
trans-unit.target: Filter Types

trans-unit.source: Azure Machine Learning Studio supports creating the following types of FIR filters:
trans-unit.target: Azure Machine Learning Studio supports creating the following types of FIR filters:

trans-unit.source: Lowpass
trans-unit.target: Lowpass

trans-unit.source: Removes high-frequency data from a signal, such as high-frequency noise and data peaks.
trans-unit.target: Removes high-frequency data from a signal, such as high-frequency noise and data peaks.

trans-unit.source: This filter type has a smoothing effect on the data.
trans-unit.target: This filter type has a smoothing effect on the data.

trans-unit.source: Highpass
trans-unit.target: Highpass

trans-unit.source: Removes low frequency data from a signal, such as a bias or offset.
trans-unit.target: Removes low frequency data from a signal, such as a bias or offset.

trans-unit.source: This filter type preserves sudden changes and peaks in a signal.
trans-unit.target: This filter type preserves sudden changes and peaks in a signal.

trans-unit.source: Bandpass
trans-unit.target: Bandpass

trans-unit.source: Preserves the data from a signal with frequency characteristics at the intersection between the highpass and lowpass filters.
trans-unit.target: Preserves the data from a signal with frequency characteristics at the intersection between the highpass and lowpass filters.

trans-unit.source: This filter type is good at removing a bias and smoothing a signal.
trans-unit.target: This filter type is good at removing a bias and smoothing a signal.

trans-unit.source: Bandpass filters are created by combining a highpass and a lowpass filter.
trans-unit.target: Bandpass filters are created by combining a highpass and a lowpass filter.

trans-unit.source: The highpass filter cutoff frequency represents the lower cutoff, and the lowpass filter frequency represents the higher cutoff.
trans-unit.target: The highpass filter cutoff frequency represents the lower cutoff, and the lowpass filter frequency represents the higher cutoff.

trans-unit.source: Bandstop
trans-unit.target: Bandstop

trans-unit.source: Removes data from a signal with frequency characteristics that are rejected by the low pass and the highpass filters.
trans-unit.target: Removes data from a signal with frequency characteristics that are rejected by the low pass and the highpass filters.

trans-unit.source: This filter type is good at preserving the signal bias and sudden changes.
trans-unit.target: This filter type is good at preserving the signal bias and sudden changes.

trans-unit.source: Window Functions
trans-unit.target: Window Functions

trans-unit.source: Azure Machine Learning supports the following types of windowing functions for use in finite impulse response filters:
trans-unit.target: Azure Machine Learning supports the following types of windowing functions for use in finite impulse response filters:

trans-unit.source: Hamming
trans-unit.target: Hamming

trans-unit.source: The <newTerm>generalized Hamming window</newTerm> provides a type of weighted averaging, which is commonly used in image processing and computer vision.
trans-unit.target: The <newTerm>generalized Hamming window</newTerm> provides a type of weighted averaging, which is commonly used in image processing and computer vision.

trans-unit.source: Blackman
trans-unit.target: Blackman

trans-unit.source: A <newTerm>Blackman window</newTerm> applies a smoothly tapered curve function to the signal.
trans-unit.target: A <newTerm>Blackman window</newTerm> applies a smoothly tapered curve function to the signal.

trans-unit.source: The Blackman window has better stopband attenuation than other window types.
trans-unit.target: The Blackman window has better stopband attenuation than other window types.

trans-unit.source: Rectangular
trans-unit.target: Rectangular

trans-unit.source: A <newTerm>rectangular window</newTerm> applies a consistent value inside the specified interval and applies no value elsewhere.
trans-unit.target: A <newTerm>rectangular window</newTerm> applies a consistent value inside the specified interval and applies no value elsewhere.

trans-unit.source: The simplest rectangular window might replace <legacyItalic>n</legacyItalic> values in a data sequence with zeros, which makes it appear as though the signal suddenly turns on and off.
trans-unit.target: The simplest rectangular window might replace <legacyItalic>n</legacyItalic> values in a data sequence with zeros, which makes it appear as though the signal suddenly turns on and off.

trans-unit.source: A rectangular window is also known as a <newTerm>boxcar</newTerm> or <newTerm>Dirichlet window</newTerm>.
trans-unit.target: A rectangular window is also known as a <newTerm>boxcar</newTerm> or <newTerm>Dirichlet window</newTerm>.

trans-unit.source: Triangular
trans-unit.target: Triangular

trans-unit.source: A triangular window applies filter coefficients in a step-wise fashion.
trans-unit.target: A triangular window applies filter coefficients in a step-wise fashion.

trans-unit.source: The current value appears at the peak of the triangle, and then it declines with preceding or following values.
trans-unit.target: The current value appears at the peak of the triangle, and then it declines with preceding or following values.

trans-unit.source: None
trans-unit.target: None

trans-unit.source: In some applications it is preferable not to use any windowing functions.
trans-unit.target: In some applications it is preferable not to use any windowing functions.

trans-unit.source: For example, if the signal you are analyzing already represents a window or burst, applying a window function could deteriorate the signal-to-noise ratio.
trans-unit.target: For example, if the signal you are analyzing already represents a window or burst, applying a window function could deteriorate the signal-to-noise ratio.

trans-unit.source: Examples
trans-unit.target: Examples

trans-unit.source: For examples of how filters are used in machine learning, see this experiment in the <externalLink><linkText>Model Gallery</linkText><linkUri>http://gallery.azureml.net/</linkUri></externalLink>:
trans-unit.target: For examples of how filters are used in machine learning, see this experiment in the <externalLink><linkText>Model Gallery</linkText><linkUri>http://gallery.azureml.net/</linkUri></externalLink>:

trans-unit.source: The <externalLink><linkText>Filters</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=525732</linkUri></externalLink> experiment demonstrates all filter types.
trans-unit.target: The <externalLink><linkText>Filters</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=525732</linkUri></externalLink> experiment demonstrates all filter types.

trans-unit.source: The example uses an engineered waveform dataset to more easily illustrate the effects of the different filters.
trans-unit.target: The example uses an engineered waveform dataset to more easily illustrate the effects of the different filters.

trans-unit.source: Technical Notes
trans-unit.target: Technical Notes

trans-unit.source: FIR filters have these characteristics:
trans-unit.target: FIR filters have these characteristics:

trans-unit.source: FIR filters do not have feedback; that is, they use the previous filter outputs.
trans-unit.target: FIR filters do not have feedback; that is, they use the previous filter outputs.

trans-unit.source: FIR filters are more stable, because the impulse response will always return to 0.
trans-unit.target: FIR filters are more stable, because the impulse response will always return to 0.

trans-unit.source: FIR filters require a higher order to achieve the same selectivity as infinite impulse response (IIR) filters.
trans-unit.target: FIR filters require a higher order to achieve the same selectivity as infinite impulse response (IIR) filters.

trans-unit.source: Like other filters, the FIR filter can be designed with a specific cutoff frequency that preserves or rejects frequencies that compose the signal.
trans-unit.target: Like other filters, the FIR filter can be designed with a specific cutoff frequency that preserves or rejects frequencies that compose the signal.

trans-unit.source: Calculating Coefficients over the Filter Window
trans-unit.target: Calculating Coefficients over the Filter Window

trans-unit.source: The window type determines the trade-off between selectivity (width of the transition band in which frequencies are neither fully accepted nor rejected) and suppression (the total attenuation of frequencies to be rejected).
trans-unit.target: The window type determines the trade-off between selectivity (width of the transition band in which frequencies are neither fully accepted nor rejected) and suppression (the total attenuation of frequencies to be rejected).

trans-unit.source: The windowing function is applied to the ideal filter response to force the frequency response to zero outside of the window.
trans-unit.target: The windowing function is applied to the ideal filter response to force the frequency response to zero outside of the window.

trans-unit.source: Coefficients are selected by sampling the frequency response within the window.
trans-unit.target: Coefficients are selected by sampling the frequency response within the window.

trans-unit.source: The number of coefficients returned by the <ui>FIR Filter</ui> module is equal to the filter order plus one.
trans-unit.target: The number of coefficients returned by the <ui>FIR Filter</ui> module is equal to the filter order plus one.

trans-unit.source: The coefficient values are determined by filter parameters and by the windowing method, and are symmetric to guarantee a linear phase response
trans-unit.target: The coefficient values are determined by filter parameters and by the windowing method, and are symmetric to guarantee a linear phase response

trans-unit.source: See the <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_Notes" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Technical Notes</legacyLink> section for an example of the trade-offs between these characteristics.
trans-unit.target: See the <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_Notes" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Technical Notes</legacyLink> section for an example of the trade-offs between these characteristics.

trans-unit.source: Scaling of Coefficients
trans-unit.target: Scaling of Coefficients

trans-unit.source: The <ui>FIR Filter</ui> module returns filter coefficients or tap weights for the created filter.
trans-unit.target: The <ui>FIR Filter</ui> module returns filter coefficients or tap weights for the created filter.

trans-unit.source: The coefficients are determined by the filter, based on the parameters you enter (such as the order).
trans-unit.target: The coefficients are determined by the filter, based on the parameters you enter (such as the order).

trans-unit.source: If you want to specify custom coefficients, use the <link xlink:href="53f113fe-2e9d-45dd-a421-cdd7ada0567b" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">User Defined Filter</link> module.
trans-unit.target: If you want to specify custom coefficients, use the <link xlink:href="53f113fe-2e9d-45dd-a421-cdd7ada0567b" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">User Defined Filter</link> module.

trans-unit.source: When <ui>Scale</ui> is set to <legacyBold>True</legacyBold>, filter coefficients will be normalized, such that the magnitude response of the filter at the center frequency of the passband is 0.
trans-unit.target: When <ui>Scale</ui> is set to <legacyBold>True</legacyBold>, filter coefficients will be normalized, such that the magnitude response of the filter at the center frequency of the passband is 0.

trans-unit.source: The implementation of normalization in <token>ProductName</token> is the same as in the <system>fir1</system> function in MATLAB.
trans-unit.target: The implementation of normalization in <token>ProductName</token> is the same as in the <system>fir1</system> function in MATLAB.

trans-unit.source: Typically, in the window design method, you design an ideal infinite impulse response (IIR) filter.
trans-unit.target: Typically, in the window design method, you design an ideal infinite impulse response (IIR) filter.

trans-unit.source: The window function is applied to the waveform in the time domain, and multiplies the infinite impulse response by the window function.
trans-unit.target: The window function is applied to the waveform in the time domain, and multiplies the infinite impulse response by the window function.

trans-unit.source: This results in the frequency response of the IIR filter being convolved with the frequency response of the window function.
trans-unit.target: This results in the frequency response of the IIR filter being convolved with the frequency response of the window function.

trans-unit.source: However, in the case of FIR filters, the input and filter coefficients (or tap weights) are convolved as follows when applying the filter:
trans-unit.target: However, in the case of FIR filters, the input and filter coefficients (or tap weights) are convolved as follows when applying the filter:

trans-unit.source: Let <math>n</math> be the length of the input signal and <math>m</math> be the number of taps.
trans-unit.target: Let <math>n</math> be the length of the input signal and <math>m</math> be the number of taps.

trans-unit.source: Then <legacyItalic>y</legacyItalic><subscript> j </subscript>=∑<superscript> m </superscript><subscript> i=1 </subscript><legacyItalic>b</legacyItalic><subscript> i </subscript><legacyItalic>x</legacyItalic><subscript> j−(i−1) </subscript><legacyItalic>j</legacyItalic>=1..<legacyItalic>n</legacyItalic> where the values <math>x</math><subscript>j-(i-1)</subscript><math>=0</math> if <math>j-(i-1) %%amp;lt; 1</math>.
trans-unit.target: Then <legacyItalic>y</legacyItalic><subscript> j </subscript>=∑<superscript> m </superscript><subscript> i=1 </subscript><legacyItalic>b</legacyItalic><subscript> i </subscript><legacyItalic>x</legacyItalic><subscript> j−(i−1) </subscript><legacyItalic>j</legacyItalic>=1..<legacyItalic>n</legacyItalic> where the values <math>x</math><subscript>j-(i-1)</subscript><math>=0</math> if <math>j-(i-1) %%amp;lt; 1</math>.

trans-unit.source: Selectivity and Stop Band Attenuation
trans-unit.target: Selectivity and Stop Band Attenuation

trans-unit.target: The following table compares selectivity with stop band attenuation for a FIR filter with length <legacyItalic>n</legacyItalic> by using different windowing methods:
